Monoid
A set $M$ with a law of composition $\sigma: M \times M \longrightarrow M$ is called a monoid if $\sigma$ is associative and $M$ admits a unit element with respect to $\sigma$.
Right Coset
Let $G$ be a group and $H$ a subgroup of $G$. A right coset of $H$ in $G$ is a subset of $G$ of the form $Ha = \{ha; h \in H\}$, where $a \in G$.
Leading Coefficient

For a polynomial f=
sum a_i X^i in R[X] with deg f=n 
geq 0, the coefficient a_n is called the leading coefficient. If a_n=1, the polynomial is called monic.
Sum of Ideals
For ideals $\mathfrak{a}, \mathfrak{b}$ in a ring $R$, the sum $\mathfrak{a}+\mathfrak{b}$ is defined as $\{a+b ; a \in \mathfrak{a}, b \in \mathfrak{b}\}$.
Factorial ring/unique factorization domain

An integral domain $R$ satisfying the conditions that every element $a \in R-\left(R^{*} \cup\{0\}\right)$ can be uniquely written, up to associatedness and order, as a product of irreducible elements, and every element $a \in R-\left(R^{*} \cup\{0\}\right)$ is a product of prime elements. An element of a unique factorization domain is irreducible if and only if it is prime.
A-homomorphism
Homomorphisms between A-modules, also referred to as A-homomorphisms, are defined just as in the context of vector spaces.
Minimal Polynomial

The minimal polynomial of an element \\(\alpha\\) in a field extension is the monic polynomial of lowest degree in the base field that has \\(\alpha\\) as a root. It is a prime polynomial and generates the kernel of the evaluation homomorphism from the polynomial ring of the base field to the field generated by \\(\alpha\\). 
(Alt.2)
Let $K \subset L$ be a field extension and $\alpha \in L$ an element that is algebraic over $K$. The unique monic polynomial $f \in K[X]$ of smallest degree such that $f(\alpha)=0$ is called the minimal polynomial of $\alpha$ over $K$.
Integral Ring Homomorphism
A ring homomorphism $\varphi: A \longrightarrow B$ is integral if every element $b \in B$ is integral over $A$ in the way described in the definition of an integral element over a ring.
Algebraic Closure of Finite Field

An algebraic closure $\\[\overline{\mathbb{F}}_p\]$ of a finite field $\\[\mathbb{F}_p\]$ is a field that contains $\\[\mathbb{F}_p\]$ and all its algebraic extensions. It is used to view the fields $\\[\mathbb{F}_{p^n}\]$ as subfields.
Galois group of a Field Extension
The Galois group $\\operatorname{Gal}(L / K)$ of an extension $L / K$ is the group of all field automorphisms of $L$ that fix every element of $K$.
p-group
A finite group G is called a p-group if the order of G is a power of p, where p is a prime number.
Codomain
The codomain of a function is the set that contains all potential output values, even if some of those values are not actually produced by any input in the domain.
Definition_Association_Analysis

Implied_Association_Relationships.Explanation: A right coset is defined in terms of a group and a subgroup. Therefore, the concept of a group must be defined to understand what a right coset is.
The sum of ideals is defined in terms of ideals, which are subsets of a ring. Therefore, the concept of a ring must be defined to understand what an ideal is.
A unique factorization domain is a type of integral domain, which is a specific kind of ring. Therefore, the concept of a ring must be defined to understand what a unique factorization domain is.
An A-homomorphism is a homomorphism between A-modules, which are generalizations of vector spaces. Therefore, the concept of a module must be defined to understand what an A-homomorphism is.
The minimal polynomial is defined in terms of a field extension and polynomials over a field. Therefore, the concept of a field must be defined to understand what a minimal polynomial is.

An integral ring homomorphism is defined in terms of a ring homomorphism and integral elements over a ring. Therefore, the concept of a ring must be defined to understand what an integral ring homomorphism is.

The algebraic closure of a finite field is defined in terms of a finite field and its algebraic extensions. Therefore, the concept of a finite field must be defined to understand what an algebraic closure is.
The Galois group of a field extension is defined in terms of field automorphisms and field extensions. Therefore, the concept of a field must be defined to understand what a Galois group is.
A p-group is defined in terms of a finite group and the order of the group being a power of a prime number. Therefore, the concept of a group must be defined to understand what a p-group is.
